projects.title: Intership Universidade de São Paulo, Solid-state Physics and Low Temperatures
projects.description: I have investigated the light emitting properties of quantum dots, which are submicroscopic structures which have completely different electronic behaviour than bulk material. Applications of this research lie in the field of lasers and quantum computers. With the help of photoluminescence excitation, I have investigated its light emitting properties. The outcome was that due to the inhomogeneity of the quantum dots in size, Ga content and strain, 10% of the quantum dots is emitting light.

projects.title: Bachelor Thesis Organic Magnetoresistance
projects.description: OMAR (organic magnetoresistance) is an effect in organic materials with nonmagnetic electrodes that display a low-field, room-temperature  magnetoresistive effect in organic devices. The research is OMAR is interesting because of its applications in organic light-emitting diodes, photovoltaic cells and field-effect transistors. I constructed an analytical bipolaron model, found analytical expressions for the current, the linewidth and magnitude of OMAR curves. Moreover, not only hopping in forward direction, but also in backward direction are included. The analytical bipolaron model can be compared with a Monte Carlo simulation and many similarities are found.

profile_positions.description:
•	Master thesis work awarded with a publication in Plasma Sources Science and Technology: http://iopscience.iop.org/0963-0252/22/5/055014/. 

•	Low-temperature atmospheric pressure plasmas have been receiving an increasing interest for biomedical applications for their both oxidative and bactericidal effects.  These plasmas generate a mixture of highly reactive radicals and molecules, of which the most important one is the hydroxyl radical. 
•	In order to determine the hydroxyl ground state density, laser induced fluorescence is used. I developed a model and a calibration, with the help of Rayleigh scattering for deducing the absolute hydroxyl density in the plasma. I proved the results to be consistent with those of absorption measurements. The advantage of using laser induced fluorescence compared to absorption is the ability to resolve the results in both space and time.
